blogs.author: https://shkspr.mobi/blog/2015/05/how-gmail-lets-spammers-grab-your-attention-with-emoji/
paragraphs:
The animated GIF lives at https://mail.google.com/mail/e/B69 where it is used for the web version of Gmail.
For most of us, the character "󾭩" doesn't display as any meaningful symbol - but on the web version of Gmail, it shows up as: , a flashing star.
Google and other members of the Unicode consortium are also developing a proposal for the addition of standardized Emoji symbol characters to Unicode.
An ancient form of Emoji, probably all but forgotten, has been resurrected by spammers in the hope that you'll notice their wares.
This is a trend I've recently started to see on Gmail - here's what it looks like and how it works.
blogs.header: How Gmail lets spammers grab your attention with emoji ← Terence Eden's Blog

blogs.author: http://techcrunch.com/video/y-combinator-incubated/518389021/
paragraphs:
But how does YC do it?
What sets it apart from some of the other accelerators out there, and why does it seem like its alumni companies are disproportionately successful?
Y Combinator is the most famous of all startup accelerators out there, thanks to success of companies like Airbnb, Dropbox, and Stripe, all of which have gone through its program.

blogs.header: You Can Never Size a Market in Excel — on startups — Medium
blogs.author: https://medium.com/on-startups/you-can-never-size-a-market-in-excel-786886d11f50#.6t6oxias0
paragraphs:
You Can Never Size a Market in ExcelOver the course of my career as a VC I’ve been involved with a bunch of fundraising.
Questions about “market size” and “opportunity” at this stage seemed peculiar.
And I’ve seen well intentioned VCs burn meeting after meeting with these entrepreneurs genuinely trying to resolve this nagging concern for themselves.
Of the raises that have fallen into the latter category I’ve seen a common theme.
In every single case that I’ve seen this question persist over more than 2 meetings, it has NEVER been resolved.

blogs.header: Everything You Know About Latency Is Wrong – Brave New Geek
paragraphs:
Instead of pausing for 100 seconds after 100 seconds of perfect operation, it handles all requests at 5 ms each after 100 seconds.
If you measure 10,000 things in the first 100 seconds, you have to measure 10,000 things in the second 100 seconds during the stall.
Before freezing, we run 100 seconds at 100 requests/second for a total of 10,000 requests at 1 ms each.
Now consider what happens when we freeze the system (for example, using CTRL+Z) after 100 seconds of perfect operation for 100 seconds and repeat.
If our test is generating 100 requests/second, we run 10,000 requests in the first 100 seconds.
blogs.author: http://bravenewgeek.com/everything-you-know-about-latency-is-wrong/

blogs.header: Some memories from meeting Einstein in 1951 – 1952
blogs.author: http://cqgplus.com/2015/12/14/some-memories-from-meeting-einstein-in-1951-1952/
paragraphs:
Though concentrating on unified theory, Einstein was still interested in classical General Relativity and its open mathematical problems.
Some ten years ago, a new interpretation was given to this non-symmetric Einstein theory by Damour and Deser.
Returning to 1951: after my introduction by Leray, Einstein invited me into his office.
I showed that these solutions satisfy the Cauchy problem for the quasilinear Einstein equations in harmonic coordinates.
In fact Einstein’s conjecture was stronger: he thought that the result should hold for any asymptotically Euclidean complete vacuum Einsteinian spacetime.

blogs.header: Loopt's Sam Altman on Why He Sold to Green Dot for $43.4M
paragraphs:
Loopt’s Sam Altman on Why He Sold to Green Dot for $43.4MMobile location start-up Loopt will be acquired by the banking company Green Dot, best-known for its prepaid cards.
Back when the trend was toward asking users to actively note their own location, Loopt changed to a check-in model in 2009.
In a phone interview this morning, Loopt CEO Sam Altman described the deal as an opportunity to make location more accountable.
At this point, though, it’s only the latest location app to be acquired and see its own product shut down, following others like Gowalla and Yobongo.
Loopt’s products are to be shut down at an unspecified date, while its 30 employees will now comprise Green Dot’s Silicon Valley-based mobile product development team.
blogs.author: http://allthingsd.com/20120309/green-dot-buys-location-app-loopt-for-43-4m/

blogs.header: Building my own email app to reach Inbox Zero.
blogs.author: http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/technology/2015/02/email_overload_building_my_own_email_app_to_reach_inbox_zero.html?wpsrc=sp_all_native_by-section
paragraphs:
The first task I had to solve in building my email client was to synchronize email on my computer with the email on the email server.
Email clients that are associated with an email provider often bear its name—“Gmail” could mean either Google’s email client or Google’s email service, or both—but they’re two separate things.
There are too many dependencies on it.” My email client will treat my email despair, but I don’t believe it can be cured.
Your email client must download the statuses of potentially tens of thousands of email IDs, simply to reflect a single change.
Sure, that means experimenting with email apps and workflows to find the perfect combination for you or even, if you’re crazy, developing your own email client.
